CatDescriptText: Miss Josephine E. Williams, 49 Bellevue Avenue, Trenton, N.J., and Mrs. Carrie Means, 624 Morgan Street, was part of the "Pittsburghers Speak Up" column published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, August 24, 1957, pg. 2 with question: "Does Pittsburgh Need Negro Police Inspectors?" Miss Josephine E. Williams' answer reads: "I'm indeed surprised to learn that your city does not have Negro police inspectors. We havve had them in Trenton for quite some time.  For the number of Negroes in Pittsburgh, your city should have at least one."  Mrs. Carries Means' answer reads: "Yes, I think Pittsburgh should have Negro police inspectors.  We are just the same as any other race and therefore we should be represented just the same on the police force."
TitMainTitle: Group portrait of Josephine E. WIlliams, wearing dark dress with light colored floral pattern, and light colored beaded necklace, Carrie Means, and unknown woman, standing on sidewalk in front of brick building with dark awnings
